context: As <a0_0><b5_0>civil wars engulfed several Central American countries in the 1980s<a0_0/>,<b5_0/> hundreds of thousands of <a1_0>Salvadorans fled their country and came to the United States. Between 1980 and 1990<a1_0/>, <a2_0>the Salvadoran immigrant population in the United States increased nearly fivefold from <b7_0>94,000<b7_0/> to <b8_0>465,000<b8_0/>.<a2_0/> The number of Salvadoran immigrants in <a3_0>the United States continued to grow in the 1990s and 2000s as a result of family reunification and new arrivals fleeing a series of natural disasters<a3_0/> that hit El Salvador, including <b9_0>earthquakes and hurricanes<b9_0/>. <a4_0>By 2008, there were about <b6_0>1.1 million<b6_0/> Salvadoran immigrants in the United States.
